A 9/11 Remembrance Ceremony was held at Stevenson this morning with many area first responders in attendance.

This highlight offers a glimpse of this morning's ceremony.

The event was organized by the co-curricular club Students Helping Soldiers, along with club sponsors Dino Moran and Vicki Kieft, and with the support of many community members. Although this was a closed event, students involved with SHSTV and their sponsor Joe Pine streamed the ceremony live this morning.

During the ceremony, Moran recalled the events which occured 19 years ago and honored victims and first responders. The National Anthem was sung by junior Michelle Cabrera and Taps was played by senior Leah Roginsky.

All incoming freshmen are required to have a physical exam and submit completed immunizations dated within 12 months of the first day of school. Transfer students will need to submit a copy of the 9th-grade physical submitted to their former school or complete a new physical. See a detailed explanation at: https://www.d125.org/students/health-services-nurses

Seniors are required to submit documentation that they have had a Meningococcal (MCV4) vaccination after the age of 16.

Also, transfer students who have never attended a school in Illinois will need to submit documentation of an eye exam.

All forms should be submitted to nurses@d125.org

Students who register are required to attend a virtual Orientation Meeting on Monday, Sept. 7 at 8 p.m. Please see the SHS Contact Days Information Document for more information.

Tomorrow, Stevenson will be a national host site for the SAT exam.

Students who have pre-registered for this exam will be instructed to check-in at one of four stations. Two check-in stations will be located in Parking Lot C and two will be located in Parking Lot D.

Safety procedures, materials students should bring and instructions for exiting the building once the exam is completed can be read at: https://www.d125.org/checkin

The College Career Center will hold its annual Senior Parent Night from 7-8:30 p.m. Monday, Aug. 31 via Zoom.

The event is free and open to all parents and guardians of seniors at Stevenson. During the presentation, postsecondary counselors Sara English and Dan Miller will discuss how to apply to colleges.

Topics to be covered include types of applications (Common App, for example), admission plans (including Early Decision), deadlines, obtaining a transcript, standardized test scores, letters of recommendation, essays, and scholarships.

Parents can access this presentation through the Zoom link: https://zoom.us/j/98006670532

There will be a special session for parents and guardians of students with IEP/504 plans from 6:30-6:50 p.m. Families can join this pre-session through this Zoom link: https://zoom.us/j/96655274708.

Some Stevenson students have received an invitation to join a for-profit scholastic honor society called National Society of High School Scholars. The invitation states that students were selected for membership based on their achievements at SHS.

To clarify, Stevenson is not affiliated with this organization, has not released student names to this group and does not recommend students pay for a chance to receive college scholarships.

We will be back next year, stronger, better and healthier. I’m already thinking of themes!!
Let me know if you have any ideas.

If you're wondering if you can use alcohol wipes on school-issued iPads, the Stevenson SMARTdesk staff indicates you can but you need to do it carefully following these directions:

• To clean the iPad, unplug all cables and turn it off (press and hold the Sleep/Wake button, and then slide to power off).
• Use a soft, slightly damp (alcohol only, never water), lint-free cloth.
• Avoid getting moisture in any openings.
• Don't use window cleaners, household cleaners, compressed air, aerosol sprays, solvents, ammonia, abrasives, or cleaners containing hydrogen peroxide to clean an iPad.
• Avoid getting moisture in any openings.
• The iPad has an oleophobic coating on the screen. The school provides a glass screen protector for the screen.
• Simply wipe the iPad's screen protector with a soft, lint-free cloth to remove oil left by your hands.
• Rubbing the screen or screen protector with an abrasive material might scratch your screen.

Students who have questions or who need cleaning supplies should see the staff at the SMARTdesk located in Room 3014.

Congratulations Patriots!

The SHS boys swimming and diving team earned three medals at the Illinois High School Association state meet Saturday at Evanston Township High School.

The 200-yard medley relay team of seniors AJ Carollo, Jack Zhang and Jake Kim, and sophomore Josh Song placed fifth with a time of 1:33.38.

Sophomore Jack White finished sixth in 1-meter diving with a score of 457.90, and Josh added an eighth-place showing in the 100-yard butterfly (49.96).

Zhang finished his career with four state medals. In addition to one this year, he was part of medal-winning 400 free relays in 2018 and 2019, and in the 200 medley relay last year. AJ earned his second state medal after swimming in the 400 free relay in 2019. All of Stevenson‘s other medalists this year were first-timers.

See the SHS Instagram page for a recap of White's state medal-winning dives: https://www.instagram.com/p/B9SJUD1JoNy/

Today, Stevenson juniors taking U.S. History had an opportunity to attend a presentation by Holocaust survivor Steen Metz.

The SHS Social Studies Division coordinates this event each year. Metz is shown here with Social Studies teacher Michelle Stone and division director Brad Smith who organized the presentation.

Students were introduced to Metz by Stone and SHS junior Laya Reddy. They watched a Holocaust overview video prior to hearing a first-hand account of the Holocaust from a survivor.

Steen Metz was a young boy living in Denmark prior to the Nazi occupation of that country. He was deported with his family to the Theresienstadt Concentration Camp in Czechoslovakia in 1943. Today, Stevenson students heard about his experience and how he survived.

You can learn more about Steen Metz, who has spoken to groups around the country since 2012, on his website: http://www.steenmetzneverforget.com/

It's a wrap for Give-A-Thon 2019 at Stevenson.

This is the 35th year Stevenson students and families have spread holiday cheer to local families in need. Students involved in the SHS National Honor Society chapter organized the event with the help of 700 students who served as classroom leaders. Many departments, clubs and teams also organized collection efforts and online donations were received from community members.

This year, 285 local families, or a total of 1,500 people, will receive festively wrapped presents.

In addition, enough baby items to serve a PADS Lake County, Inc. shelter for nine months was collected and enough non-perishable food was donated to serve the Vernon Township Food Pantry for six months.

Give-A-Thon at Stevenson is something to see. If you weren't here to witness it as a student, faculty or staff member, or parent volunteer this video will give you a glimpse into this annual event.

Booths representing SHS co-curricular clubs Peer Helpers, Mind Your Mind, FIRE as well as Stevenson Student Support Teams and community resources provided additional information.

The months of November and December are often a time to give thanks and give back. Junior Luke Snider isn't letting the season define when and how he shows his appreciation.

Luke recently donated $3,555 to the Advocate Charitable Foundation to benefit the Cranial Facial Clinic at Advocate Children's Hospital - Park Ridge. He raised this money by holding a garage sale fundraiser in September.

Luke wanted to give back to the hospital that helped him so much. Luke was born with a cleft lip and palate and has had 18 surgeries throughout his life. He is scheduled for another operation next summer.

Through his many surgeries and follow-up visits at the hospital, Luke noticed many other youngsters in similar situations. The September garage sale, which had a goal of raising $1,000, was organized to help them.

Read more about Luke's fundraising efforts: https://www.d125.org/about/news/news-post/~board/student-news/post/junior-donates-3555-to-advocate-childrens-hospital

This is a Patriot who is showing his commitment to others regardless of the season.

Through his many surgeries and follow-up visits at the hospital, Luke noticed many other youngsters in similar situations. The September garage sale, which had a goal of raising $1,000, was organized to help them.

Read more about Luke's fundraising efforts: https://www.d125.org/about/news/news-post/~board/student-news/post/junior-donates-3555-to-advocate-childrens-hospital

This is a Patriot who is showing his commitment to others regardless of the season.

Two Stevenson students started Crescendo for a Cause, a non-profit organization, to improve music education in underserved areas and to use music performance to provide community service.

Seniors Allen Beckwith and Kiran Mohan are very involved in SHS band and orchestra programs and Beckwith also performs with the Buffalo Grove Symphonic Band.

Their efforts to bring live jazz to residents of Belmont Village Senior Living as well as other area teen and senior programs was recently chronicled by the Daily Herald.

In addition, they are collecting instruments, music stands and lesson books to donate to programs that provide free music education to underserved children in Chicago.

Their work also extends to a fundraiser and performance goal that they have as part of #ChildhoodCancerAwarenessMonth

Part of Stevenson's Portrait of a Graduate is a commitment to others. These Patriots are a great example of what that looks like.
